addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

16 July
1592
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.

page.lettertext:
fol.106r
May it please your good L. The 10 of this moneth
being come as farre as
Swolle,
in going towardes
the campe, and there attending
e arrival of
e
Councel of Estate
, I receaved those letters and
schedules, w
ch
her
Ma
tie
and my
LL.
and yo
r
L.
sent unto me, bearing date
e 1 and 2 of this
present. When
e Councel was come thither,
w
ch
was
e next day after, having commoned
first w
t
S
r
Francis Vere
, I procured an assemblie
not onely of
e Councel, but of
e Deputies of the
Provinces, and I offered them to open her Ma
ties
letters to
e states, in case they founde themselves
thereto to be sufficiently autorised. Whiche I did
for good respect, for
at it had bin a question in
their dealinges before, whether they in
at place, or
those at
e Hage having both like commission
from
e generallitie of
e contrey, were to exer-
cise
e power of
e general states. But in this
mater of her Ma
tie
they disclamed
at autoritie,
and putte me over to
e Hage for deliverie of my
letters. Howbeit I omitted not to signifie the
effect of those letters, and in all
at I was able to
amplifie
e reasons, and to pray them not to
hinder
e exceution of my charge. For her Hig
nes
promise was so past,
at it could not be revoked,
and I had order thereafter, to cause
e troupes
that were desired, to putte themselves in present
readines. They were muche amased at
the mater, and used great intreatie,
at no sepa-
ration might be made of
e Englishe from the
rest, till
e campe were come to
Coevoerden:
upon hope
at
e Enemie, upon
e viewe of their
nombers, would come to present composition.
fol.106v
But conferring upon it w
t
S
r
Francis Vere, and per-
ceaving plainely by discourse,
at it was but a
motion to gaine a litle time, for
at
e Enemie is
hardie and
e place well provided: and finding
therew
t
all
at their marching first to Coevoerden,
and then afterwardes to
Flushing,
might both weaken
them in strength, and putte them farre out of
order, when her Hig
nes
would be served, I persisted
precisely upon
e pointes of my charge, and req
e
sted
them earnestly, to graunt a patent to every com-
pany to repaire to his garrison, and
at there they
might remaine, untill suche time as they were sent
for. This I urged continually, as having no kinde
of libertie, to dispose in other sort of her Ma
ties
de-
signe: w
ch
was also so confirmed by S
r
Francis
unto them: who continueth there in place, and hath
resolved not to alter but to prosecut
e mater, as I
have begonne it. In
e meane time, because they
did refuse to determine there upon it, referring
me hither to this assemblie of
e states, I departed
from thens
e next day folowing, and came hither to
the Hage w
t
all possible speede. I left
e campe
at
at time w
t
in a mile of Swolle, from whens I thinke
they will not sturre, till they heare w
at
is said by
e
states of this place. Yesterday morning I
presented my letters in their publike meeting, whiche
when I had heard, being openly read, (for I had no
copie sent unto me) I noted a certaine clause, w
ch
I
am very muche afraid will put me to some troble.
For it goeth w
t
condition,
at if
e armie of
e states
may be commodiously dissolved, and
e forces of her
Ma
tie
w
ch
have served in
e armie, conveniently re-
turned, that then
e
F
r
King
shall have
e use of
those succo
rs
,
at are promised unto him. But, as
if I had not understoode it, I urged very earnestly
fol.107r
e Kinges necessitie, and
e importance of
e ma-
ter in respect of these contreis, and proposed all
the pointes of
e instructions sent unto me, w
t
out
leaving to
eir choise, to denie her Hig
nes
her demaunde.
They saide but litle as then to any part of my speeche,
but as their custome is commonly in causes of conse-
quence, they required some time to signifie their
answear. They had notice of
e mater, before
my comming to
e Hage, and had receaved out of
England
a copie of
e Contract between her Hig
nes
and
e King: w
ch
I perceave by some frindes, they
doe highly dislike to have bin done w
t
out their pri-
vitie, in regard of
at Contract, w
ch
is made w
t
them already. But if they seeme in
at respect
to complaine in publike place, I have mater enough
for answear. I am onely nowe to seeke, w
ch
way
I shall be able to reconcile
e forsaid clause, w
t
at
w
ch
I proposed. For as I learne underhand by a
frind among
e states, they doe minde to take hold
of those wordes of
e letter, and will seeme to take
no knowledge,
at her Ma
tie
meant otherwise, but to
make her suite conditional. I will excuse it as I
may upon
e writers oversight, and keepe
e course
that is begonne in preparing
e companies, and in
declaring plainely to them,
at both
e Contract w
t
e
King, and her Ma
ties
letter to my self, doth appa-
rantly signifie that there must be no denial. Ne-
vertheles if they chance to be so wilfull, as to st
a
d
in contestation, and to oppose against me, as they
may, it will be greatly behoofull,
at I be streng-
thned from her Hig
nes
w
t
some plainer knowledge of
her meaning. And because it is a mater of so
great a consideration, I thought w
t
all speede to
advertise yo
w
of it, and humbly to beseeche yo
w
, to
write about it w
t
e soonest. I have
certaine intelligence from
e campe, at this very instant,
fol.107v
15 July 1592
That S
r
Francis Vere hath obtened
patents
for his troupes, to
be placed in townes adjoining to Swolle, and
at
the rest of
e campe is marched towardes Coevoerd
e
I am also told assuredly,
at
e answear of
e
states
is ready to be sent and is framed up
o
e advan-
tage of
e point aforementioned.
Count Phi-
lip
w
t
his troupes
at have served in France, is expe-
cted every houre: and assoone as they returne,
M
r
Buzenval
hath in charge, to request
e loane of so
muche mony, as may suffice for certaine monethes,
to intertene 2000 men, to be levied in suche sort,
as
e King shall appoint. And for mine owne
part I beleve, he shall speede of his purpose. For
if they in this contrey, shall be forced to surcease from
an offensive warre, as me thinkes there is appa-
rance, when
e Englishe are departed, there will
be so muche remaining of this sommers contribution,
as the King may be pleasured, and an overplus re-
served.
And thus I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. July 15 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
fol.108r
When the bearer was ready to depart w
t
my
letter,
e states sent unto me a transcript of
their answear: w
ch
I caused out of hand to be
copied againe, and I send it heere unto yo
r
L.
For it may chaunce to come before
e originall
letter, w
ch
they will send some other way. I see
their answear is no other, then I expected at their
handes, taking holdfast of
at clause of her Ma
ties
l
re
. I should mervel not a litle, that they
calle me not againe, to some further communicati
o
,
but that they knowe well enough,
at I will pro-
secute
at course,
at I have hitherto proposed, and
endevo
r
what I can, to put
e companies in a
readines. Their answear is also general
for
e motion of
Britaine:
but no doubt in par-
ticular, they will come to
at w
ch
was their offer.
And for
e day of their letter, though they dated
it for yesterday, it was signed but to day: w
ch
is
e custome of their college, to put the date of
e day, when they take their resolutions, and not
of
e time when their letters are signed.
July 16.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
